sub_title: Marine plastic expert - Sustainability strategist - Science communicator - PhD
summary:
Hello! I'm Hanna, a PhD candidate studying the societal and business case for preventing plastic pollution and managing marine litter with the Institute for Environmental Studies at the Vrije Universiteit. 

I wear many hats in teaching and research: as a lecturer, course coordinator, teaching and field work assistant, grant writer, Twitter contributor, EU project member and thesis supervisor. 

My recent work has focused on solutions to (marine) plastic pollution, with focus on the circular economy, sustainable business and entrepreneurship. Earlier work included research on ecosystem services and community climate change adaptation strategies. I conducted field work research on Pacific small island developing states in Palau and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. 

I am curious about how innovative ideas, individuals and groups contribute to - or detract from - sustainability progress. 

Let's connect if you want to discuss marine litter and the innovative ways we can tackle the plastic soup!

profile_positions.description:
I am a sustainability strategist and consultant with experience analyzing the societal and business case for (marine) plastic pollution management. I work at the intersection of science, business and society through impactful strategizing, targeted research and engaging communication. I am currently available for freelance research, consulting and communication work. 

Find me at www.HannaDijkstra.com

Examples of work include
- Content lead in charge of developing a suite of content (articles, guides, case studies) for a sustainable tourism website. This included research, writing, editing and overseeing two interns. 
- Project management for sustainable tourism website development, including liaising with the client, development and design teams.
- Stakeholder coordination and consultation, creating stakeholder maps, identifying partners and pursuing collaboration opportunities for a sustainability project in the Middle East.
- Framework development and strategy for an online community of practice centered around plastic pollution management on islands.
- Methodology training on the multi-criteria decision support tool to a team of four consultants.
- Grant writing for a non-profit seeking funding for a plastic collection and recycling project in the Caribbean.

profile_positions.description:
Junior Researcher for the Environmental Economics department at IVM - Institute for Environmental Studies. In this role I work with other researchers at IVM, external partners  and students at Vrije University to conduct research and assist in projects ranging from teaching assistance and coordination to presentating results to stakeholders. 

Highlights include: 
-  Conducting economic analyses such as cost-benefit analysis and ecosystem service dependence in Pacific Island communities, including Mejit Island, Wotho Atoll in the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and Melekeok, Palau. Research involved field work, household surveys, key informant interviews as well as data analysis and presentation of findings to communities and stakeholders. 
- Assisted in finalizing data analysis and reports for the EU Horizon 2020 project FATIMA: Farming tools for external nutrient inputs and water management. 
- Published a report on sustainable finance mechanisms for nature conservation in the Caribbean in collaboration with JNCC. 
- Worked on various projects in partner with WWF, including an assessment of the effectiveness of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) globally. For more information see https://www.mpaaction.org. -
- Prepared a scoping report for WWF involving four case study locations (Aceh, Guianas, Zambezi & Chaco-Pantanal).
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher

profile_positions.description:
I conducted my thesis research on climate change adaptation options in Palau, using household surveys and discrete choice experiment (DCE) methodology to value ecosystem services in a small community. The research is part of a greater study spearheaded by The Nature Conservancy and numerous other organizations titled 'Building the Resilience of Communities and their Ecosystems to the Impacts of Climate Change' which is focusing on small island developing states in the Pacific region. The research will allow policy makers, researchers and most importantly communities to plan adaptation options that maximize welfare while minimizing risks and costs.  

The Master Environment and Resource Management (ERM) is designed to train the next generation of environmental decision-makers to work on the sustainability challenges of our time. Students learn to work towards finding solutions for societal problems related to natural resource depletion and environmental change.
